Len- There is a detailed introduction on later prophecy and halakhah in R. Margaliot, She’elot u-Teshuvot min ha-Shamayim (1957); Ta Shema, On Shut Min Hashamayim, Tarbitz 57 (1988). Rav Kook discusses shut min hashamayim in his halakhic work. From other perspectives, see Heschel, Heavenly Torah, Moshe Idel has some articles about medieval Jewish prophets and Yuval Cherlow in his Torat E”Y has in the followers of Rav Kook. These articles have the sources.

item.title: By: Len Moskowitz
item.dc:creator: Len Moskowitz
item.description:
It's a fascinating interview.
It seems that he hinges his argument of Jesus being rightly convicted as a false prophet based on the phrase "o-tote u'mofe-sim" being code words for "sent by God" (i.e., a true prophet of God). And then he cites the Baal Ha-Turim as a source supporting that conclusion.
I thought that the existence of prophecy in Israel concluded with the Anshei K'nesset Ha-g'dola (the Great Assembly) around the time of Ezra (around 500 BCE), after the end of the Babylonian exile.
Does anyone have any more insight into Weiler's reasoning?
Does anyone have the supporting citation from the Baal Ha-Turim?
item.content:encoded:
It’s a fascinating interview.

It seems that he hinges his argument of Jesus being rightly convicted as a false prophet based on the phrase “o-tote u’mofe-sim” being code words for “sent by God” (i.e., a true prophet of God). And then he cites the Baal Ha-Turim as a source supporting that conclusion.

I thought that the existence of prophecy in Israel concluded with the Anshei K’nesset Ha-g’dola (the Great Assembly) around the time of Ezra (around 500 BCE), after the end of the Babylonian exile.

Does anyone have any more insight into Weiler’s reasoning?

Does anyone have the supporting citation from the Baal Ha-Turim?
